title: Why Co-Ownership Changes Luxury Real Estate (w/ Spencer Rascoff & Austin Allison) | Masters of Scale

rawLines.text: We were pretty scared at the beginning.

I I think we thought that this
 startup
was DOA u for the first couple months

post co starting
 from you know zero to
um I don't know billion and a half was
our series C valuation which we did in
like the first 18 months. We were
operating in 3540 markets. We had 3 to
400 people. I mean, we were growing
fast, hundreds and hundreds of percent
year-over-year, and then the music

stopped.
 We started Zillow in 2005,
moving into the 2007208 global financial
crisis, which was a real estate and
mortgage meltdown. I've seen this movie
before a couple times. I'm Jeff Burman,
your host. This week on the show,
Picasso co-founders Austin Allison and
Spencer Rascoff share hard one lessons
from their real estate related
businesses. Loop and Zillow. We talk
about how those experiences now inform
the meteoric rise of Picasso, their new
vacation home company.
This is Masters of Scale.
Austin Spencer, welcome to Masters of

Scale.
 Thank you.
 Good to be here.
 I
have been looking forward to this
conversation ever since uh my friend and
I'm guessing you were certainly your
investor Marcy Vu told me about Picasso
and I was like, "Oh my god, this is
genius. How has this not been done
before? Um, so Austin, maybe we start
with you just what is Picasso? What what

what do you guys do?
 Yeah, so Picasso is
a global marketplace that enables people
to co-own luxury vacation homes. Uh, and
the reason why we exist is because most
people who own a vacation home only use
it five or six weeks a year. So our
model enables people to buy what they
actually need, which for most people is
about 1/8 of a home. For some people
it's more. It can be a quarter or 1/2.
And then we manage every part of the
experience. Everything from designing
the home to paying the bills to
coordinating repairs and maintenance so
that as an owner you get to just use the
home without any of the headaches that
are customary of traditional home

ownership.
 I mean it sounds a lot like a
time share but but what's what's
different about Picasso from time share?
Well the biggest difference is that with
Picasso you actually own an asset
whereas with a time share you're
effectively prepaying for the right to
use time in a hotel. So, it's kind of
like comparing an asset to a liability.
The better analog for Picasso would be
buying a home with friends. If the three
of us wanted to own a home in, you know,
Mexico or wherever our dream destination
is, the way that we would go about doing
that is we'd form an LLC. The LLC would
take ownership of the property and then
we would divvy up the the calendar and
divvy up responsibilities. Picasso's
ownership structure is exactly the same
except for you don't have to know the
other people and Picasso manages all the
details. We've now been around for 4 and
1/2 years. We've sold, you know, well
over a billion dollars of these Picasso
units. We have thousands of owners and
operate in uh about 40 destinations
around the world. What usually happens
is about half of the home is spoken for
by the time we close. We then take
temporary ownership of the other half of
the home and we have great financing
partners that enable us to finance that
and then we sell through the remaining
interest over a period of about 90 days
thereafter and once the home is fully
subscribed by its owners. Picasso
retains no ownership in the real estate.
So you as a Picasso owner get all the
upside in the capital appreciation that

occurs in the home.
 So how do you guys
make money then if you're not holding on
to any share of the property? Where

where do you guys get paid?
 Well, we
think about the business like a tech-
enabled marketplace that offers lots of
services within the marketplace. And
many of those services produce revenue
for us. So, the first service is the uh
organizing the group of co-owners and
sourcing the property and setting up the
LLC. And um that we monetize through a
service fee that is baked into the share
price. So when you look at a a property
on our website in that share price is a
little fee for us for all the work that
we do on the front end. Then once the
home gets into our ecosystem it stays in
the Picasso ecosystem into perpetuity in
most cases because once somebody buys a
a share of a home if they decide to
resell at a future date they're not
triggering a whole home sale. They're
just selling their interest whether it's
a fourth or an eighth. And uh therefore
all the other services that we provide
from financing to property management to
design and furnishing to resell are are
all revenue streams for us that are

recurring in nature.
 Where did the idea
come from? How how did this get started?
Well, uh I grew up uh a real estate
agent. When I was 18 years old, I had to
find a way to pay for college. So I
started selling real estate, which led
to I know you went you went to law

school as well, right?
 I I I I did,
although my classmates would tell you I
barely went, but yeah. So yeah, I I went
to law school as well and ended up
starting a real estate tech company in
my first year of law school to digitize

real estate transactions,
 which we ended
up selling to Zillow and that's how I
got to know Spencer really well, which
which led to this company, which I'm
sure we'll talk about. But along the
way, that entrepreneurial journey led my
wife and I to San Francisco. I was from
Cincinnati, but we raised our series A
from uh Trinity Ventures in San
Francisco. uh fell in love with
California and and and ultimately fell
in love with Lake Tahoe. And in 2013, my
wife and I had an opportunity to buy a
second home in Lake Tahoe. And it just
changed our lives for the better. If
you've reached a point in your life
where you have some discretionary income
and you have some savings, uh a second
home is is kind of the ultimate
privilege because it it provides a
separate space where you can be a better
version of yourself. Whether it's a
better partner, a better husband, uh a
better hobbyist. Like I used to always
love mountain biking when I was growing
up, but I never made time for it in my
primary home in Cincinnati or San
Francisco. It wasn't until we had this
home in Lake Tahoe where I rekindled my
relationship with mountain biking and
that's now a really important part of my
life. So, this Lake Tahoe home really
kind of became an important part of our
lives and I wanted to find a way to to
make it possible for more people. But
the other thing that I learned about
second home ownership is that it's a
huge hassle. Even people who can afford
second, third, fourth, you know, tenth
homes, uh, they they don't like hassle.
They don't like stress. And trying to
operate a property in a difficult market
that's hundreds of miles away is is a
lot of hassle. So, we wanted to we
wanted to find a better way. We wanted
to find a more efficient way. Um,
because when second homes are sitting
empty 10 months a year, which is the
norm, it creates all these other
downstream problems for communities.
Spencer, when did Austin come bring you

this idea?
 We both left about five and a
half, six years ago. We both left Zillow

at the same time. And
 after, we should
say the tremendous run at Zillow. I

mean, a lot of success there.
 Yeah.
About 15 years or so of of running
Zillow and it was it was a great run and
I'm very proud of what we accomplished.
When Austin and I both left about six
years years ago, we immediately started
brainstorming startup ideas. I had a
another idea in the sharing economy
space about something else that I was
interested in and and then Austin
improved upon that idea and and applied
that concept to second home ownership.
And as soon as he said it, I said,
"Yeah, that's a good point. I have an
empty second home that sits there 92% of
the year and drives me nuts and it's the
cost. It's the hassle. It's also the
stress and sense of guilt." So, it was
immediately I immediately realized it
was a good idea. And it's a another good
way to find startup ideas is to find
things that people hack themselves that
um in kind of an an okay way. And people
have hacked this. Friends buy ski houses
together, beach houses together, etc.
And it usually doesn't work out. Usually
you argue over the furnishings. You have
a hard time with the scheduling. You
can't get a mortgage. I mean, one of the
big benefits of buying a Picasso is you
can get a mortgage on just your portion
of the home because Picasso created that
financing instrument. Um, so you can't
get a mortgage and you can't really
resell. If the three of us bought a home
together, what happens when one of us
wants to get out? It's like, you know,
is are the other two going to be saddled
with a stranger, etc. And so Picasso
solves the resale model. We solve the
storage issue as well because you want
to keep things at your home and we have
owner closets in all of our homes so
people um keep their personal effects in
our Picasso. So we thought this was
something that's already happening kind
of on a small scale in a hacky way that
we could democratize and standardized.
When was this conversation when you were
walking along looking at the ocean and

and building on each other's ideas?
 Uh
it was I would say early to mid 2019.

Okay. So we're pre pandemic.
 Yeah.
Precoid. Yes. And and you launched the
company in the week before co I think
well we raised our seed round uh on

February 15th of 2020.
 Okay. So a few
weeks before the world shut down. Yeah.
We were pretty scared at the beginning.
I I think we thought that this startup

was DOA uh for the first
 couple months
post co starting. It turned out to be an
incredible tailwind to the business
because people wanted a a sanctuary.
They wanted to get away from their
primary home, away from the city and
have a a place to feel safe and secure.
And so the Picassos that they purchased
were able to provide that. But it was

dark days at the very beginning.
 Well,
and I assume also just the move to
remote and hybrid work gave gave
opportunity there as well. That had to
be part of the tailwind. But but before
we get to to that growth part like the
those dark days
I mean you guys have done well
Zillow and Do Loop you guys have done
great. Um but still you're founder
you're starting a company like your
heart your soul your everything's in it
emotionally. Um what were those days
like how were you managing through that
with each other?
The way that I've managed through
challenging times whether it was 2020 or
uh 2009 when I started my first company
uh is to just stay focused on the
mission like I've any I've started two
companies now where I was CEO and in
both situations I was incredibly
passionate about the problem that we
were solving and if you believe deeply
in the problem that you're solving it
serves as a north star to help you
navigate through whatever challenges
you're facing. So, I I didn't actually
think Spencer may have thought we were
DOA. I didn't actually think we were
DOA, you know, when CO happened. Um, I
just wasn't sure how we would have to
evolve, you know, to find product market
fit. Um, but like I I knew there was a a
there there. I knew that people aspired
to own a second home. I knew that it was
silly for people to own a 100% of
something that they were only going to
use 10% of the time. Uh I just didn't
know how we were going to solve that

problem.
 Was there a point, Spencer,
where you realized, oh, not only are we
not DOA, like we're we're really on to

something here?
 Yeah. And that and that
happened very quickly. And you know,
I've now been doing this for a long
time, been doing this for almost 30
years. And I've seen this a couple
times. We had this at Hotwire,
Hotwire.com, online travel company after
9/11 in 2001 where it seemed like the
company was on the ropes and we were an
online travel company through September
11th and people didn't want to travel
and then through a lot of hard work and
focus on the mission we were back on the
upswing within a couple quarters and and
then had a successful exit and we
started Zillow in 2005 moving into the
2007208 global financial crisis which
was a real estate and mortgage meltdown.
It looked like Zillow was going to be on
the ropes and we managed to pull through
and then Picasso similar thing started a
home sharing business moving into a
global pandemic. So I've seen this movie
before a couple times and um Austin's
absolutely right. Staying focused on the
mission,
staying focused on your team,
controlling the things that you can
control, um caring deeply about your
customers and being nimble. Like these
are all they sound kind of trit but if
you follow that recipe that's how you
manage through adversity and um we've
had our fair share at Picasso actually
frankly the more almost existential
challenge more so than co really was the

rise in mortgage rates
 and that hit the
brakes on really most real estate
transactions whole home partial home

everywhere in between
 and so managing
through that set of challenges I think
was even more difficult in a lot of ways

than managing through early co
 what you

to manage through that.
 So we grew from
you know zero to um I don't know billion
and a half was our series C valuation
which we did in like the first 18
months. We were operating in 3540
markets. We had 3 to 400 people. I mean
we were growing fast hundreds and
hundreds of percent year-over-year. Um
and then the music stopped. So
fortunately, we had raised a big series
C just prior to this and Spencer and I
had both gone through challenging
economic cycles in the past and the last
thing you ever wanted have or the last
thing I or Spencer ever wanted to have
to do as a founder was downsize the

team.
 Sure.
 Uh and we tried to plan for
that as we were growing. Like we knew we
expected that this growth, you know,
would eventually slow down, but we
didn't expect that it would slow down as
quickly or as dramatically as it did. So
we had to downsize the team. uh and we
did it you know with class I think and
took care of everybody and you know many
of those people are now hiring back
which is really awesome. Uh but that was
hard you know we had to cut our cost
basis so that was number one. Uh number
two we had to focus in on the markets
where we had the most scale and the
strongest product market fit. Was there
a concern with Picasso now given that
you're you know in higherend markets
where there tend to be more restrictions
on not just fractional ownership but you
know Airbnb has trouble operating a lot
of these markets right was there a
concern that you'd be running a foul of
local regulations you run into some

trouble there
 the main thing that we've

learned from it is that
 it's really
important to be proactive and not
reactive on this front. So anytime we're
entering a market or you know innovating
on a product offering or something like
that, we're two steps ahead in in terms
of talking to local electeds, making
sure we understand the rules and rags in
that market. So we structured Picasso
now in such a way that you know it it
was compliant in the same way that our
our core ownership experiences. I mean,
this is really kind of the opposite of
the Uber and Airbnb approach, which is
like, f it. Like, yolo, we're coming in,
we're going to do it, we'll pay a price
later on, we'll activate a user base to

our
 We had a little bit of that
 um

bravado at the beginning.
 You know, like
people are very emotional for good
reason about the composition of their
neighborhoods.
I think some of the public affairs
issues that some other sharing economy
businesses faced were more about
disrupting legacy industries that had um
you know lobbyists and entrenched

interests.
 Home ownership is is really
different. It's pretty it's quite
emotional and people care a lot about
who owns the house next door and what
does that mean to the neighborhood and
are they emptying the trash cans and is
the house in good order and and these
types of things. Um does it change the
character of the neighborhood? And so
we've gotten a lot smarter about where
we operate, how we operate, the way we
form relationships with the communities
that we're in and um I'm I'm quite proud
of the impact that we've had on
communities, but we also made mistakes
along the way. Picasso has faced some
resistance from neighbors and local
officials, specifically in Northern
California. Many of the critics are
already frustrated by what happens in
communities when guests come in on
short-term rentals. And they were
worried that Picasso's fractional
ownership model would degrade their
neighborhoods.
So, when we first started getting
feedback, you know, in in Napa is where
it all started, or St. and Helina
actually um I just kind of ignored it
because I'm like, you know, these people
just don't understand like this is
actually a great thing for them. These
are not renters. These are owners who
have invested, you know, millions of
dollars who care about the home. They
care about the community. They're
supporting the local charities. It's not
changing the character of the
neighborhood. So, I just ignored the
noise, thinking it would go away. But
what ended up happening was the noise
didn't go away. you know, the the noise
built and perception became reality. And
before we knew it, many people in these
communities thought that Picasso was
like a short-term rental and that it was
going to be this revolving door of
renters and party. Yeah. That owners
were partying and that we were driving
up home prices and none of that stuff

was true.
 Spencer, you you referenced
Hotwire, Zillow, Picasso. By the way,
you're also CEO of Match Group now.
Well, not quite. And and you run an
investment fund and you teach at
Harvard. I mean, it's a little
mindboggling what all that you do, but
like going way back, where where did
this entrepreneurial drive, this this
zeal come from?
Um, I I mean, I grew up, I I think sort
of like Austin, always tinkering and
starting businesses. I would bake
cookies and sell them to my parents'
friends. I would trace drawings and sell
them to my parents' friends. And I was
always trying to make money, sell,
arbitrageing comic books and, you know,
doing whatever I can to start companies
and and try to build things. Um, my dad
was an entrepreneur in the music
industry and that was very inspiring to
me. I watched his career as a early
producer and and tour producer and
business manager of rock groups and
watched him pivot his career over many
decades as the music industry changed.
And that was an inspiration for me. And
then my sense of drive and um ambition I
think came from the fact that I lost my
brother in high school and he was the
eve of his high school graduation and he
was going to Princeton and he was going
to have I'm sure a very successful life
which was cut short and that motivated

me to try to kick ass
 and I'm still

still trying.
 Yeah.
Why still try so hard? I mean you you
you you've I mean you've had
extraordinary success. Um you'd be
understood for wanting to have three or
four Picasso properties and spend a lot
of time traveling among them. Um what
what's driving you to to still innovate?
Life is short and um I think you should
make a big impact in it. And um I you
know I'm not ready to just play golf and
I don't even really I'm not very good at
golf and I don't even like it that much.
Um, I like working with teams. I like
coaching and mentoring. I I think, you
know, the role that I play at Picasso is
as Austin's co-founder is, uh, Austin
runs it and he's the CEO and I'm I'm
just here to help. And I really like
that. I like coaching and mentoring.
Whether it's a company that I'm running
like Zillow as CEO or now Matchcript as
CEO where I'm working with people and
building camaraderie and teams as a CEO
coach or if it's a company that I've
invested in or a company that I've
co-founded. I just really like
connecting with people and trying to
help them succeed. So I mean I left
Zillow about five five six years ago and
for those five years I what I did was I
focused on incubating new startups
mostly with former Zillow people. And so
I started four or five companies.
Picasso is the largest of them, but
there are several others that um I'm
co-founder and chair of. And then I also
did some angel investing. So that was a
period of my career where I was really
focused on the zero to one stage of
startups. And as part of that, I also
started teaching this course on on how
to do startups at Harvard College, which
I've been doing for 5 years. Um, I
decided to get back in the arena as a
full-time CEO just a couple months ago
as CEO of Matchgroup because I was so
interested in the mission because
Matchgroup owns Tinder and Hinge and 20
consumer social and dating apps. For me,
curing loneliness,
driving sparking meaningful connections,
helping people find a spouse, partner,
friend, anywhere in between. That
inspires me. I think that's a really
cool exciting mission. I love the power
of those brands. they're global and
they're the category leaders in in the
online dating space and the meeting new
people space. And so I connected enough
with the mission to decide to put the
cleats and jersey back on and get back
on the field as a full-time CEO. Um, and
so I'm not angel investing anymore. I'm
still working with folks like Austin,
whose companies I I helped start, but
I'm, you know, I'm not launching new
initiatives. I'm I'm a full-time CEO of

a big publicly traded company now.
 And
with with Match, um, as someone who's
not in the dating market, um, How is it
running a consumer company where you're
not actually a user of the product?
Well, I am a user of the product now. I
I mean, I'm very happily married. I've
been with my wife for more than 30
years, but I'm on all the apps and she's
a she's a trooper. She's a good sport. I
get notifications all the time of, you
know, this this person just sent you a
rose and this, you know, this this uh
this person is chatting with you and
this person's waiting for you to

respond.
 Be careful which way you swipe.
Yeah. So, so she's a good sport about
it. Um and and that I I mean, I need to
be on the apps. I said to her when I
took the job, I was like, can you
imagine if I was running Zillow and I
never used any real estate apps? Like, I
I can't I can't do that. So, you have to
be you have to have consumer empathy
that comes from using your own products
and spending a lot of time talking to
your users. So, I do use the products.
My profiles all say I'm the CEO of of
the company. I'm just here to learn,
just here to research. So, I disclose my
uh you know, my the fact that I'm I'm
I'm not single. Um, but I mean more to
the point though, I think you can
develop user empathy through research
and just spending a lot of time with the
users. Actually, teaching my class is
really helpful because that is our demo.
Gen Z 18 to 24 is the primary um user of
Tinder Hinge and our other apps. So,
spending a lot of time on college
campuses, which I do, is really
valuable. Having a 20-year-old in
college and a 16 and 13y old is actually
really useful because they're the ones
that are using consumer social apps like
Snap and Tinder and and so that's also
where I learn. Before Austin and Spencer
co-founded Picasso, they worked together
at Zillow. That's thanks to a year'slong
professional courtship where Spencer as
CEO of Zillow eventually acquired
Austin's startup. Looploop
was a software tool to streamline the
process of buying property. I was
curious to hear how that acquisition
played out from both sides of the deal.
Um, okay. So, Spencer, how do you find
out about DLO?
Um, it had a big great reputation in the
industry. I would see, you know, hear
about it in conferences and, um, the
courtship, the kind of mutual courtship
between Austin and me was several years.
And it's actually worth reflecting on
that for a moment for startup founders
listening to this. Zillow bought 17
companies. I bought 17 companies when I
was CEO. Do Loop was one of them. The
median time from when I first shook
hands with the founder of those 17
companies to when those 17 wires crossed

was about 2 years.
 Wow.
 And I don't
remember what do loop was. Probably
longer. Probably three years I'm
guessing of how long we knew each other
and we'd see every couple of quarters
and we'd catch up and you know have a
cup of coffee at a conference or an
event. And so it's really important for
startup founders to remember that
because companies don't get sold, they
get bought. And it I always advise
startup founders to make a list, create
a spreadsheet of every potential
strategic acquirer of your company, 5,
10, 20, 50 companies ideally. Figure out
who the CEO is and the head of corp dev.
And be very intentional long before you
want to sell. Start building those
relationships and carve out time on your
calendar. literally block an hour a
month to call it, you know, M&A planting
seeds. And during that hour, I'm going
to pick up the phone and reach out to
two or three of these people. And you're
just calling to say, "Hey, just, you
know, can we have coffee at the next
conference? I want to tell you what
we're up to. We're doing cool stuff,
innovating. You know, when the company's
not for sale, let's talk about potential
partnership or ways to work together.
Just want to get to know you better,
etc." And then a couple years later that

can that can become
 I mean I think this
is phenomenal advice and but for a lot
of startup founders they're probably
scared hearing this. They're like well
but I'm going to go tell this behemoth
this 800 lb gorilla what we're doing
like I'm going to inform their product

roadmap.
 Um it is it is a small risk.
The potential upside far exceeds that
potential downside. the chances of a
competitor whether it's a big potential
acquirer or even another startup
learning something from that
conversation and going and replicating
it is is very low it's not zero but it
is quite low and the potential upside is
really significant so I mean if if
Zillow if and if in every one of those
conversations over a couple years you
were really worried about it I mean the
truth is at Zillow if we had really
wanted to go knock off doloop I didn't
really learn anything from those
conversations with Austin that would

have made that more likely.
 Maybe it
would have opened my eyes to the
opportunity and that might have caused
me to go internally and say, "Hey, let's

spin up a team and try to do this."
 But
again, more likely it opened my eyes to
the opportunity and caused me to want to
acquire the company, which is what
happened. Do Loop had a really good
brand and strong network effects and
important customer relationships. And
so, um, if Zillow were to try to we
could have built the product, perhaps
the technology, but, uh, there was a lot
more to it. So obviously founders are
going to want to think this through
themselves, but I I always heir on the
side of commu overcommunicating about

your idea.
 Yeah, I think it's worth
noting that there are a handful of
companies out there where reputationally
they do this and it's good to do a
little bit of research ahead of time
before you hit everyone on that list.
But but by and large, this is not this

is not how the world works.
 No. Yeah. I
mean, and I was always very careful
about that at Zillow that um I thought
our reputation as an acquirer was very

important and
 um I don't you probably
did some references from some other
companies that we had bought before you
decided to I'm guessing before you
decided to sell and it was very
important that we had a lot of founders
whose companies we bought that stuck
around for many years like Austin did
and um and the rest of his team did
until the rest until that most of that
team that you brought into Zillow left
to go and start Picasso But um so so the
buyer reputation is very important.
Why'd you sell to Zilla?
Well, you know, one of the things that I
was thinking as Spencer was talking is
that I I agree with everything you just
said. I think it was hugely important
that I had that relationship built. Um
so I would recommend the same. But at
the time when I was building that
relationship, I wasn't thinking about it
as Zillow might be our acquirer. In
fact, I was just like absolutely adamant
against the idea of selling. I viewed
selling as a failure. I'm like, we're
building this company to take it public
and we're going to do it. And anything
short of that is a failure. So selling
never crossed my mind. I was only
building the relationship with Zillow
and and there was like one or two other
companies like this that I was also
building a relationship with because I

admired the company
 and I was thinking

Right? Same thing that that I was

Zillow and that's ultimately why we sold

That would have never happened had I

 So let's come back to
Picasso today. There are rumors of going

 Uh we definitely plan to go

You know I have to disclaim that

nothing's guaranteed, right?
 Uh but
yeah, that is our our preferred path.

And
 I mean, we're in the midst of

 Fast forward 5

Uh, I would say we're we're definitely

 Guys, thanks for being on

 Thank you so much.

cleanText:
We were pretty scared at the beginning. I think we thought that this startup was DOA for the first couple months post co starting. From, you know, zero to, um, I don't know, a billion and a half was our series C valuation, which we did in like the first 18 months. We were operating in 35-40 markets. We had 3 to 400 people. I mean, we were growing fast, hundreds and hundreds of percent year-over-year, and then the music stopped.

We started Zillow in 2005, moving into the 2007-2008 global financial crisis, which was a real estate and mortgage meltdown. I've seen this movie before a couple times. I'm Jeff Berman, your host. This week on the show, Pacaso co-founders Austin Allison and Spencer Rascoff share hard-won lessons from their real estate-related businesses, Dotloop and Zillow. We talk about how those experiences now inform the meteoric rise of Pacaso, their new vacation home company.

This is Masters of Scale.

Austin, Spencer, welcome to Masters of Scale.

Thank you.

Good to be here.

I have been looking forward to this conversation ever since, uh, my friend, and I'm guessing you were certainly your investor, Marcy Vu, told me about Pacaso and I was like, "Oh my god, this is genius. How has this not been done before?" Um, so Austin, maybe we start with you, just what is Pacaso? What, what, what do you guys do?

Yeah, so Pacaso is a global marketplace that enables people to co-own luxury vacation homes. Uh, and the reason why we exist is because most people who own a vacation home only use it five or six weeks a year. So our model enables people to buy what they actually need, which for most people is about 1/8 of a home. For some people, it's more. It can be a quarter or 1/2. And then we manage every part of the experience. Everything from designing the home to paying the bills to coordinating repairs and maintenance so that as an owner, you get to just use the home without any of the headaches that are customary of traditional home ownership.

I mean, it sounds a lot like a time share, but what's different about Pacaso from time share?

Well, the biggest difference is that with Pacaso, you actually own an asset, whereas with a time share, you're effectively prepaying for the right to use time in a hotel. So, it's kind of like comparing an asset to a liability. The better analog for Pacaso would be buying a home with friends. If the three of us wanted to own a home in, you know, Mexico or wherever our dream destination is, the way that we would go about doing that is we'd form an LLC. The LLC would take ownership of the property, and then we would divvy up the calendar and divvy up responsibilities. Pacaso's ownership structure is exactly the same, except for you don't have to know the other people, and Pacaso manages all the details. We've now been around for 4 and 1/2 years. We've sold, you know, well over a billion dollars of these Pacaso units. We have thousands of owners and operate in, uh, about 40 destinations around the world. What usually happens is about half of the home is spoken for by the time we close. We then take temporary ownership of the other half of the home, and we have great financing partners that enable us to finance that, and then we sell through the remaining interest over a period of about 90 days thereafter, and once the home is fully subscribed by its owners, Pacaso retains no ownership in the real estate. So you, as a Pacaso owner, get all the upside in the capital appreciation that occurs in the home.

So how do you guys make money then if you're not holding on to any share of the property? Where, where do you guys get paid?

Well, we think about the business like a tech-enabled marketplace that offers lots of services within the marketplace. And many of those services produce revenue for us. So, the first service is the, uh, organizing the group of co-owners and sourcing the property and setting up the LLC. And, um, that we monetize through a service fee that is baked into the share price. So when you look at a property on our website, in that share price is a little fee for us for all the work that we do on the front end. Then once the home gets into our ecosystem, it stays in the Pacaso ecosystem into perpetuity in most cases, because once somebody buys a share of a home, if they decide to resell at a future date, they're not triggering a whole home sale. They're just selling their interest, whether it's a fourth or an eighth. And, uh, therefore, all the other services that we provide, from financing to property management to design and furnishing to resell, are all revenue streams for us that are recurring in nature.

Where did the idea come from? How, how did this get started?

Well, uh, I grew up a real estate agent. When I was 18 years old, I had to find a way to pay for college. So I started selling real estate, which led to... I know you went, you went to law school as well, right?

I, I, I did, although my classmates would tell you I barely went, but yeah. So yeah, I went to law school as well and ended up starting a real estate tech company in my first year of law school to digitize real estate transactions, which we ended up selling to Zillow, and that's how I got to know Spencer really well, which, which led to this company, which I'm sure we'll talk about. But along the way, that entrepreneurial journey led my wife and I to San Francisco. I was from Cincinnati, but we raised our series A from Trinity Ventures in San Francisco, uh, fell in love with California, and and and ultimately fell in love with Lake Tahoe. And in 2013, my wife and I had an opportunity to buy a second home in Lake Tahoe. And it just changed our lives for the better. If you've reached a point in your life where you have some discretionary income and you have some savings, uh, a second home is kind of the ultimate privilege because it provides a separate space where you can be a better version of yourself. Whether it's a better partner, a better husband, uh, a better hobbyist. Like I used to always love mountain biking when I was growing up, but I never made time for it in my primary home in Cincinnati or San Francisco. It wasn't until we had this home in Lake Tahoe where I rekindled my relationship with mountain biking, and that's now a really important part of my life. So, this Lake Tahoe home really kind of became an important part of our lives, and I wanted to find a way to make it possible for more people. But the other thing that I learned about second home ownership is that it's a huge hassle. Even people who can afford second, third, fourth, you know, tenth homes, uh, they don't like hassle. They don't like stress. And trying to operate a property in a difficult market that's hundreds of miles away is a lot of hassle. So, we wanted to, we wanted to find a better way. We wanted to find a more efficient way. Um, because when second homes are sitting empty 10 months a year, which is the norm, it creates all these other downstream problems for communities.

Spencer, when did Austin come bring you this idea?

We both left about five and a half, six years ago. We both left Zillow at the same time. And after, we should say the tremendous run at Zillow. I mean, a lot of success there.

Yeah.

About 15 years or so of running Zillow, and it was, it was a great run, and I'm very proud of what we accomplished. When Austin and I both left about six years ago, we immediately started brainstorming startup ideas. I had another idea in the sharing economy space about something else that I was interested in, and then Austin improved upon that idea and and applied that concept to second home ownership. And as soon as he said it, I said, "Yeah, that's a good point. I have an empty second home that sits there 92% of the year and drives me nuts, and it's the cost. It's the hassle. It's also the stress and sense of guilt." So, it was immediately, I immediately realized it was a good idea. And it's a another good way to find startup ideas is to find things that people hack themselves that, um, in kind of an okay way. And people have hacked this. Friends buy ski houses together, beach houses together, etc. And it usually doesn't work out. Usually you argue over the furnishings. You have a hard time with the scheduling. You can't get a mortgage. I mean, one of the big benefits of buying a Pacaso is you can get a mortgage on just your portion of the home because Pacaso created that financing instrument. Um, so you can't get a mortgage and you can't really resell. If the three of us bought a home together, what happens when one of us wants to get out? It's like, you know, is are the other two going to be saddled with a stranger, etc. And so Pacaso solves the resale model. We solve the storage issue as well because you want to keep things at your home, and we have owner closets in all of our homes so people, um, keep their personal effects in our Pacaso. So we thought this was something that's already happening kind of on a small scale in a hacky way that we could democratize and standardize.

When was this conversation when you were walking along looking at the ocean and and building on each other's ideas?

Uh, it was, I would say, early to mid-2019.

Okay. So we're pre-pandemic.

Yeah.

Pre-COVID. Yes. And and you launched the company in the week before COVID, I think...

Well, we raised our seed round, uh, on February 15th of 2020.

Okay. So a few weeks before the world shut down.

Yeah.

We were pretty scared at the beginning. I think we thought that this startup was DOA, uh, for the first couple months post COVID starting. It turned out to be an incredible tailwind to the business because people wanted a sanctuary. They wanted to get away from their primary home, away from the city, and have a place to feel safe and secure. And so the Pacasos that they purchased were able to provide that. But it was dark days at the very beginning.

Well, and I assume also just the move to remote and hybrid work gave opportunity there as well. That had to be part of the tailwind. But before we get to that growth part, like the those dark days...

I mean, you guys have done well, Zillow and Dotloop, you guys have done great. Um, but still, you're founder, you're starting a company, like your heart, your soul, your everything's in it emotionally. Um, what were those days like? How were you managing through that with each other?

The way that I've managed through challenging times, whether it was 2020 or, uh, 2009 when I started my first company, uh, is to just stay focused on the mission. Like I've, I've started two companies now where I was CEO, and in both situations, I was incredibly passionate about the problem that we were solving, and if you believe deeply in the problem that you're solving, it serves as a north star to help you navigate through whatever challenges you're facing. So, I, I didn't actually think Spencer may have thought we were DOA. I didn't actually think we were DOA, you know, when COVID happened. Um, I just wasn't sure how we would have to evolve, you know, to find product market fit. Um, but like I, I knew there was a there there. I knew that people aspired to own a second home. I knew that it was silly for people to own 100% of something that they were only going to use 10% of the time. Uh, I just didn't know how we were going to solve that problem.

Was there a point, Spencer, where you realized, oh, not only are we not DOA, like we're, we're really on to something here?

Yeah. And that, and that happened very quickly. And you know, I've now been doing this for a long time, been doing this for almost 30 years. And I've seen this a couple times. We had this at Hotwire, Hotwire.com, online travel company after 9/11 in 2001, where it seemed like the company was on the ropes, and we were an online travel company through September 11th, and people didn't want to travel, and then through a lot of hard work and focus on the mission, we were back on the upswing within a couple quarters and and then had a successful exit. And we started Zillow in 2005, moving into the 2007-2008 global financial crisis, which was a real estate and mortgage meltdown. It looked like Zillow was going to be on the ropes, and we managed to pull through, and then Pacaso, similar thing, started a home-sharing business, moving into a global pandemic. So I've seen this movie before a couple times, and, um, Austin's absolutely right. Staying focused on the mission, staying focused on your team, controlling the things that you can control, um, caring deeply about your customers, and being nimble. Like these are all, they sound kind of trite, but if you follow that recipe, that's how you manage through adversity, and, um, we've had our fair share at Pacaso. Actually, frankly, the more almost existential challenge, more so than COVID, really was the rise in mortgage rates, and that hit the brakes on really most real estate transactions, whole home, partial home, everywhere in between, and so managing through that set of challenges, I think, was even more difficult in a lot of ways than managing through early COVID.

What you to manage through that?

So we grew from, you know, zero to, um, I don't know, a billion and a half was our series C valuation, which we did in like the first 18 months. We were operating in 35-40 markets. We had 3 to 400 people. I mean, we were growing fast, hundreds and hundreds of percent year-over-year. Um, and then the music stopped. So, fortunately, we had raised a big series C just prior to this, and Spencer and I had both gone through challenging economic cycles in the past, and the last thing you ever wanted to have, or the last thing I or Spencer ever wanted to have to do as a founder was downsize the team.

Sure.

Uh, and we tried to plan for that as we were growing. Like we knew we expected that this growth, you know, would eventually slow down, but we didn't expect that it would slow down as quickly or as dramatically as it did. So we had to downsize the team, uh, and we did it, you know, with class, I think, and took care of everybody, and you know, many of those people are now hiring back, which is really awesome. Uh, but that was hard, you know, we had to cut our cost basis, so that was number one. Uh, number two, we had to focus in on the markets where we had the most scale and the strongest product market fit. Was there a concern with Pacaso now, given that you're, you know, in higher-end markets where there tend to be more restrictions on not just fractional ownership, but you know, Airbnb has trouble operating a lot of...


These markets, right? Was there a concern that you'd be running afoul of local regulations? Did you run into some trouble there?

The main thing that we've learned from it is that it's really important to be proactive and not reactive on this front. So anytime we're entering a market or, you know, innovating on a product offering or something like that, we're two steps ahead in terms of talking to local electeds, making sure we understand the rules and regs in that market. So we structured Pacaso now in such a way that, you know, it was compliant in the same way that our core ownership experiences. I mean, this is really kind of the opposite of the Uber and Airbnb approach, which is like, "F it. Like, yolo, we're coming in, we're going to do it, we'll pay a price later on, we'll activate a user base to our..."

We had a little bit of that bravado at the beginning. You know, like, people are very emotional for good reason about the composition of their neighborhoods. I think some of the public affairs issues that some other sharing economy businesses faced were more about disrupting legacy industries that had lobbyists and entrenched interests. Home ownership is really different. It's pretty, it's quite emotional, and people care a lot about who owns the house next door and what does that mean to the neighborhood, and are they emptying the trash cans, and is the house in good order, and these types of things? Does it change the character of the neighborhood? And so we've gotten a lot smarter about where we operate, how we operate, the way we form relationships with the communities that we're in, and I'm quite proud of the impact that we've had on communities, but we also made mistakes along the way. Pacaso has faced some resistance from neighbors and local officials, specifically in Northern California. Many of the critics are already frustrated by what happens in communities when guests come in on short-term rentals. And they were worried that Pacaso's fractional ownership model would degrade their neighborhoods.

So, when we first started getting feedback, you know, in Napa is where it all started, or St. Helena, actually, um, I just kind of ignored it because I'm like, "You know, these people just don't understand, like, this is actually a great thing for them. These are not renters. These are owners who have invested, you know, millions of dollars who care about the home. They care about the community. They're supporting the local charities. It's not changing the character of the neighborhood." So, I just ignored the noise, thinking it would go away. But what ended up happening was the noise didn't go away. You know, the noise built, and perception became reality. And before we knew it, many people in these communities thought that Pacaso was like a short-term rental and that it was going to be this revolving door of renters and party. Yeah. That owners were partying and that we were driving up home prices, and none of that stuff was true.

Spencer, you referenced Hotwire, Zillow, Pacaso. By the way, you're also CEO of Match Group now. Well, not quite. And and you run an investment fund, and you teach at Harvard. I mean, it's a little mindboggling what all that you do, but like, going way back, where did this entrepreneurial drive, this zeal, come from?

Um, I, I mean, I grew up, I think sort of like Austin, always tinkering and starting businesses. I would bake cookies and sell them to my parents' friends. I would trace drawings and sell them to my parents' friends. And I was always trying to make money, sell, arbitrageing comic books and, you know, doing whatever I can to start companies and try to build things. Um, my dad was an entrepreneur in the music industry, and that was very inspiring to me. I watched his career as a early producer and tour producer and business manager of rock groups and watched him pivot his career over many decades as the music industry changed. And that was an inspiration for me. And then my sense of drive and ambition, I think, came from the fact that I lost my brother in high school, and he was the eve of his high school graduation, and he was going to Princeton, and he was going to have, I'm sure, a very successful life, which was cut short, and that motivated me to try to kick ass, and I'm still trying.

Yeah.

Why still try so hard? I mean, you, you, you've, I mean, you've had extraordinary success. Um, you'd be understood for wanting to have three or four Pacaso properties and spend a lot of time traveling among them. Um, what, what's driving you to still innovate?

Life is short, and um, I think you should make a big impact in it. And um, I, you know, I'm not ready to just play golf, and I don't even really, I'm not very good at golf, and I don't even like it that much. Um, I like working with teams. I like coaching and mentoring. I, I think, you know, the role that I play at Pacaso is as Austin's co-founder is, uh, Austin runs it, and he's the CEO, and I'm, I'm just here to help. And I really like that. I like coaching and mentoring. Whether it's a company that I'm running, like Zillow as CEO, or now Match Group as CEO, where I'm working with people and building camaraderie and teams as a CEO coach, or if it's a company that I've invested in or a company that I've co-founded. I just really like connecting with people and trying to help them succeed. So, I mean, I left Zillow about five, five, six years ago, and for those five years, I what I did was I focused on incubating new startups, mostly with former Zillow people. And so I started four or five companies. Pacaso is the largest of them, but there are several others that um, I'm co-founder and chair of. And then I also did some angel investing. So that was a period of my career where I was really focused on the zero to one stage of startups. And as part of that, I also started teaching this course on how to do startups at Harvard College, which I've been doing for five years. Um, I decided to get back in the arena as a full-time CEO just a couple months ago as CEO of Match Group because I was so interested in the mission because Match Group owns Tinder and Hinge and 20 consumer social and dating apps. For me, curing loneliness, driving, sparking meaningful connections, helping people find a spouse, partner, friend, anywhere in between. That inspires me. I think that's a really cool, exciting mission. I love the power of those brands. They're global, and they're the category leaders in the online dating space and the meeting new people space. And so I connected enough with the mission to decide to put the cleats and jersey back on and get back on the field as a full-time CEO. Um, and so I'm not angel investing anymore. I'm still working with folks like Austin, whose companies I helped start, but I'm, you know, I'm not launching new initiatives. I'm a full-time CEO of a big publicly traded company now.

And with Match, um, as someone who's not in the dating market, um, how is it running a consumer company where you're not actually a user of the product?

Well, I am a user of the product now. I, I mean, I'm very happily married. I've been with my wife for more than 30 years, but I'm on all the apps, and she's a, she's a trooper. She's a good sport. I get notifications all the time of, you know, this, this person just sent you a rose and this, you know, this, this, uh, this person is chatting with you and this person's waiting for you to respond.

Be careful which way you swipe.

Yeah. So, so she's a good sport about it. Um, and and that, I, I mean, I need to be on the apps. I said to her when I took the job, I was like, "Can you imagine if I was running Zillow and I never used any real estate apps?" Like, I, I can't, I can't do that. So, you have to be, you have to have consumer empathy that comes from using your own products and spending a lot of time talking to your users. So, I do use the products. My profiles all say I'm the CEO of the company. I'm just here to learn, just here to research. So, I disclose my, uh, you know, my, the fact that I'm, I'm not single. Um, but I mean, more to the point though, I think you can develop user empathy through research and just spending a lot of time with the users. Actually, teaching my class is really helpful because that is our demo. Gen Z, 18 to 24, is the primary um, user of Tinder, Hinge, and our other apps. So, spending a lot of time on college campuses, which I do, is really valuable. Having a 20-year-old in college and a 16 and 13-year-old is actually really useful because they're the ones that are using consumer social apps like Snap and Tinder, and so that's also where I learn.

Before Austin and Spencer co-founded Pacaso, they worked together at Zillow. That's thanks to a year's-long professional courtship where Spencer as CEO of Zillow eventually acquired Austin's startup. Dotloop was a software tool to streamline the process of buying property. I was curious to hear how that acquisition played out from both sides of the deal.

Um, okay. So, Spencer, how do you find out about Dotloop?

Um, it had a big, great reputation in the industry. I would see, you know, hear about it in conferences, and um, the courtship, the kind of mutual courtship between Austin and me was several years. And it's actually worth reflecting on that for a moment for startup founders listening to this. Zillow bought 17 companies. I bought 17 companies when I was CEO. Dotloop was one of them. The median time from when I first shook hands with the founder of those 17 companies to when those 17 wires crossed was about two years.

Wow.

And I don't remember what Dotloop was. Probably longer. Probably three years, I'm guessing, of how long we knew each other, and we'd see every couple of quarters, and we'd catch up, and you know, have a cup of coffee at a conference or an event. And so it's really important for startup founders to remember that because companies don't get sold, they get bought. And it, I always advise startup founders to make a list, create a spreadsheet of every potential strategic acquirer of your company, 5, 10, 20, 50 companies, ideally. Figure out who the CEO is and the head of corp dev. And be very intentional long before you want to sell. Start building those relationships and carve out time on your calendar. Literally block an hour a month to call it, you know, M&A planting seeds. And during that hour, I'm going to pick up the phone and reach out to two or three of these people. And you're just calling to say, "Hey, just, you know, can we have coffee at the next conference? I want to tell you what we're up to. We're doing cool stuff, innovating. You know, when the company's not for sale, let's talk about potential partnership or ways to work together. Just want to get to know you better, etc." And then a couple years later, that can, that can become...

I mean, I think this is phenomenal advice, and but for a lot of startup founders, they're probably scared hearing this. They're like, "Well, but I'm going to go tell this behemoth, this 800-lb gorilla, what we're doing? Like, I'm going to inform their product roadmap."

Um, it is, it is a small risk. The potential upside far exceeds that potential downside. The chances of a competitor, whether it's a big potential acquirer or even another startup, learning something from that conversation and going and replicating it is, is very low. It's not zero, but it is quite low, and the potential upside is really significant. So, I mean, if, if Zillow, if, and if in every one of those conversations over a couple years, you were really worried about it, I mean, the truth is, at Zillow, if we had really wanted to go knock off Dotloop, I didn't really learn anything from those conversations with Austin that would have made that more likely. Maybe it would have opened my eyes to the opportunity, and that might have caused me to go internally and say, "Hey, let's spin up a team and try to do this." But again, more likely, it opened my eyes to the opportunity and caused me to want to acquire the company, which is what happened. Dotloop had a really good brand and strong network effects and important customer relationships. And so, um, if Zillow were to try to, we could have built the product, perhaps the technology, but, uh, there was a lot more to it. So, obviously, founders are going to want to think this through themselves, but I, I always err on the side of overcommunicating about your idea.

Yeah, I think it's worth noting that there are a handful of companies out there where reputationally they do this, and it's good to do a little bit of research ahead of time before you hit everyone on that list. But, but by and large, this is not, this is not how the world works.

No. Yeah. I mean, and I was always very careful about that at Zillow, that um, I thought our reputation as an acquirer was very important, and um, I don't, you probably did some references from some other companies that we had bought before you decided to, I'm guessing, before you decided to sell, and it was very important that we had a lot of founders whose companies we bought that stuck around for many years, like Austin did, and um, and the rest of his team did until the rest, until that most of that team that you brought into Zillow left to go and start Pacaso. But um, so, so the buyer reputation is very important.

Why'd you sell to Zillow?

Well, you know, one of the things that I was thinking as Spencer was talking is that I, I agree with everything you just said. I think it was hugely important that I had that relationship built. Um, so I would recommend the same. But at the time when I was building that relationship, I wasn't thinking about it as Zillow might be our acquirer. In fact, I was just like absolutely adamant against the idea of selling. I viewed selling as a failure. I'm like, "We're building this company to take it public, and we're going to do it." And anything short of that is a failure. So selling never crossed my mind. I was only building the relationship with Zillow, and and there was like one or two other companies like this that I was also building a relationship with because I admired the company, and I was thinking about it...


Selfishly is like, what can I learn from these guys, cuz they're doing really cool and interesting stuff, and I just want to position myself to succeed, right? Same thing that I was learning in law school, like being around really smart, competitive, hardworking people elevates your game. Um, so that is kind of like what what drove me to Zillow, and that's ultimately why we sold to them. And we were getting ready to raise our series B, and it was like a moment in time where we kind of this opportunity just came about through conversations. We weren't trying to sell, but they were interested in what we were doing. So, it kind of came up, and that put us in a position to make a decision. Do we want to sign up for a series B and go at it for another, you know, four or five years, or do we want to join forces with this bigger company and increase the probability of success in fulfilling on the mission? And that's what I chose. It was like, I believed that being part of Zillow would enable Dotloop to achieve its fullest potential. I also believed that it would benefit me and the team by being able to work closely with these other entrepreneurs and leaders who were further along in their career than I was. You know, Spencer's maybe what 10 years or so further along in his career than I am. So, there's a lot that I can learn from that. And uh, many founders leave after they sell to the company. Uh, I didn't leave, and it wasn't because of money, you know, there wasn't really much of a retention package. A little bit, but not much. Not enough to stay. The reason why I stayed is because I viewed it as an education. It was like three and a half years of incredible opportunity to up my game. You know, I was in the room, you know, as an executive with all these smart people, and it put me in a better position to be more effective at Pacaso. It led to other opportunities like co-founding Pacaso with Spencer Rascoff. That would have never happened had I just jumped ship and you know, left it to everyone else to try to make this integration work.
So let's come back to Pacaso today. There are rumors of going public.
Uh, we definitely plan to go public when we're ready and when the market is ready. That's our plan A. You know, I have to disclaim that nothing's guaranteed, right?
Uh, but yeah, that is our preferred path.
And I mean, we're in the midst of something right now, which is pretty innovative. We're in the middle of a Reg A offering, which is a way to democratize access to individual investors to be able to buy shares in private venture funded companies. It's very on message for what we are as a company. We're trying to democratize access to second home ownership, and so we're democratizing access to let individual people buy shares in the company. Um, so we are sort of quasi public. We file public financial documents with the SEC twice a year instead of four times a year, and individual investors can go to our website and actually buy shares in the company. We have earnings calls. So, so we are the shares don't trade, but they're purchasable from the company. So it's an interesting way to raise capital, and um, it's it's been great for us actually. We we love it. We think it's the future of capital, sort of capital raising at this kind of bridge moment once you're done raising venture capital from um, traditional Silicon Valley type investors. But before you're publicly traded, with companies do this, it's relatively new. It started as a result of the Jobs Act about 10 years ago as a way to try to create more capital availability for startups and a way to help individual investors have access to this asset class. So, it just hasn't been around that long. I don't think a lot of companies know about it, but I, yeah, I would say most importantly, nobody knows about it. Like I have a bunch of, you know, entrepreneur and investor friends, and most of them had never heard of this thing. And people understand crowdfunding, and they understand Reg D, which is the reg that we use to raise venture capital. But this is neither, you know, it's like it, I mean, I guess you could think of it as like a giant crowdfunded route, but it's much more analogous to going public, except for you're not traded on the other side of it. In fact, you actually are when when you go down Reg A, you're putting yourself in the company on a path to comply as a public company within a certain period of time.
Fast forward 5 years. Um, aside from the prospect of going public, uh, what's what's different about Pacaso than today?
Uh, I would say we're we're definitely bigger. You know, the the long-term vision here is to create a new category of ownership that becomes as ubiquitous in the second home space as condominiums are in a big city. Just seems inevitable to us that co-ownership is going to prevail as the preferred way for most people to own a second home. So I think we're much bigger 5 years from now. Uh, I think that swap, our we have a feature called global swap, which is just a feature on one level, but it's it's much more than a feature in terms of the value that it provides. It really provides our owners with a lot of flexibility around, you know, how they can derive value out of the Pacaso experience, and I think as our portfolio grows, the value of the swap network grows exponentially. And then the third theme is international. I think we'll have a much larger international footprint because we have made it so easy for people to buy a home that they previously think thinking about buying a home abroad, like if you live in California and you want to own a place in Paris, that is an overwhelming, you know, undertaking. With Pacaso, you can be an owner in Paris tomorrow. That's how easy it is. So I think we can do that all around the world and really make something possible that previously is felt, you know, impossible or at least impractical.
And coincidentally, Swap is the next app that Match Group is launching, I heard. So,
Oh, yeah.
Exactly.
I love it.
Guys, thanks for being on Masters of Scale.
Thank you so much.
It's incredibly impressive and so exciting to watch how Spencer and Austin are leveraging all they've learned about real estate in their earlier work into the Pacaso business model.
I'm also still struck by Spencer's advice for startup founders to be intentional about building relationships with the bigger fish in your particular pond. Even if you're not sure whether or when you might want to sell your business, Zillow's acquisition of Austin's company is a great example of how successful exits require strong relationships. One thing AI can't yet build for us. I'm Jeff Berman. Thank you for listening.
